newsitem.title: USA: Cypress sees Q3 slightly above break-even.
newsitem.headline: Cypress sees Q3 slightly above break-even.

text.p: Cypress Semiconductor Corp said Monday it will restructure operations at its San Jose wafer plant, resulting in a third quarter charge that will reduce earnings to slightly better than break-even.
Cypress will cut staff and transfer equipment and work to plants in Texas and Minnesota. It will take a $9.1 million, or $0.07 a share, charge in the quarter ending September 30.

"The restructuring will allow us to focus our San Jose facility on R&D and to significantly improve our process technology and new product development cycle time," Cypress Chief Executive Officer T.J. Rodgers said in a statement.
Analysts had expected Cypress to earn $0.11 a share, according to investment research firm First Call.

Cypress said it would cut 60 full-time positions in the San Jose plant, reducing the production capability to a prototype level for support of its research and development. Cypress employs roughly 2,000 people company-wide.
The restructuring is scheduled for completion by January 1997. The company expects to report earnings before the financial markets open on Friday, Oct. 18.
